headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Mideast Braces As Israel, Hezbollah Exchange Strikes; Democratic Pollster unpacks Challenges Ahead For Harris; Democrats Bullish On Senate Amid Delicate Dance With Harris; Schumer, Peters, Abortion Rights Will Drive Fall Turnout; Dems Try To Flip Script, Talk Tough And Blame Trump on Border; Comedian Brings Impersonations Of Harris, Trump, Obama To DNC. Aired 11a-12p ET

utterances.speaker: MANU RAJU, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Inch by inch.

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: America, we are not going back.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: As the race enters its next phase --

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.sentences: Should I get personal?

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Will Harris get a bump?

utterances.speaker: OPRAH WINFREY, MEDIA MOGUL
utterances.sentences: We can't wait to leave here and do something.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Or can Trump take back the momentum?While an escalation, Israel and Lebanon raises alarm in the U.S. Plus, reality check. SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY): This is manna from heaven.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: We go one-on-one with democratic leaders.SEN. GARY PETERS (D-MI): I'm very confident we're going to have 50 seats.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: They're bullish on November, but is the map too difficult for them to overcome?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: We know how to reach average voters.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And hearing voices.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We're in the middle of a sad speech. It's a horrible day.The comic who's gone viral for his impersonations.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, let me just say it is great to be with you.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Inside politics, the best reporting from inside the corridors of power starts now.(MUSIC) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Good morning. And welcome to INSIDE POLITICS SUNDAY, live this hour. I'm Manu Raju.Welcome to the next phase of the campaign. There are now just 72 days until the election. In just two weeks, some voters in battleground North Carolina will begin receiving mail-in ballots. The next presidential debate is on September 10th. And before the end of next month, half a dozen worst dates will have kicked off in-person early voting. Now the big question. Will this race emerge in neck-to-neck slog across key battlegrounds? Or will Kamala Harris capitalize on her party star-studded convention last week and keep that momentum going? But first, there's some news from the Middle East this morning with Israel saying it launched preemptive strikes against Hezbollah in Lebanon and Hezbollah launching a barrage of rockets into Israel. And for more, we're joined by my colleague Jeremy Diamond, who is live in Haifa in Northern Israel. Jeremy, so tell us what happened overnight and about the concerns that may exist, about this spiraling into a larger regional conflict.

utterances.speaker: JEREMY DIAMOND, CNN JERUSALEM CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Manu, over the course of a few hours early this morning, we witnessed some of the most intense exchanges of fire between Israel and Hezbollah since the beginning of this war.Starting at around 4:00 A.M. local time, about 100 Israeli fighter jets carried out what the Israeli military has described as a preemptive strike on dozens of rocket launcher sites in southern Lebanon. Trying to head off, what they said, was an anticipated large- scale attack by Hezbollah against Israel. And then it was at about 5.30 A.M. that sirens began sounding across Northern Israel and the Golan Heights as Hezbollah fired hundreds of rockets and drones at targets in Northern Israel. The Israeli military says that that Hezbollah rocket attack caused, quote, little damage. The Israeli Prime Minister, for his part, says that all of the drones that were fired were indeed intercepted. Those, the Israeli military believes, were headed for strategic targets in Central Israel. So for now, at least, it appears that we are heading off the risk of a broader regional escalation, at least in the immediate future. Hezbollah, for its part, has said that at least for today, its attacks have concluded, although they have said that this was just the first phase of their response to the Israeli military's killing of their senior military commander about a month ago. In Israel, security restrictions that were imposed earlier in the day were lifted just several hours later. And the Israeli Prime Minister, though, warning that this is not the end of the story. So there still is, indeed, some uncertainty. And, of course, all of this is happening as those ceasefire negotiations are set to get back underway in Cairo, Egypt today. We know that an Israeli delegation has landed in Cairo, set to resume those negotiations, whether Hamas is actually engaging in those talks, still very much uncertain, as is the prospects of actually reaching a deal in those talks. Manu.

utterances.speaker: CLEVE WOOTSON, WHITE HOUSE REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Things are getting a lot harder though. So, what is their strategy in this next phase of the campaign?

utterances.speaker: WOOTSON
utterances.sentences: Well, the strategy is to just keep it going, right? But I think there's two things that are happening. One, the debate, which was mentioned earlier, but also you really can overstate the importance of this interview that she's going to do the first interview, unscripted, un-teleprompter. She's not going to see the questions that are coming ahead of her.Remember, the first year of her tenure was largely defined by a bad interview. And so I think both her opponents and her allies are going to be wanting to see how she handles this.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, that's going to be the really -- I mean, this campaign is going to get a lot harder for her.

utterances.speaker: MOLLY BALL, SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think the feeling is that the convention opened the door, but now she has to lock down the people who have maybe decided to give her a look, right?I think the convention was about putting her over that threshold of believability. All of the optics of that speech, right? The dark suit, the wood paneling, the flags. It was all about this sense of sort of gravitas and seriousness. She needs to -- she needs, you know, those undecided voters who may not have initially been open to her candidacy to see her as a serious candidate who is presidential and who is ready to walk into that job. But I think for a lot of those voters, they are -- they may be open to her candidacy, but she hasn't necessarily sealed the deal. So I think Cleve is exactly right. It's those unscripted appearances that have the potential to either convince or put off those voters. And it's hearing more about these policy plans. She did start to lay out an agenda in her convention address, but it was much more about goals and values than it was about specifics. And I think a lot of people want to hear more about that as well.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's really been. It would light on policy this whole campaign, both Trump and Harris.And Harris. So you guys have mentioned more values, more how we're different than Donald Trump and how they went after Donald Trump, which was notable about some of the way they tried to poke fun at Donald Trump or tried to undercut his credibility through the course of the -- course of the convention, just a taste of what some of the speakers said. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I heard someone compare Trump to the neighbor who keeps running his leaf blower outside your window every minute of every day.Now, from a neighbor, that's exhausting. From a president, it's just dangerous. REP. HAKEEM JEFFRIES (D-NY): Donald Trump is like an old boyfriend who you broke up with, but he just won't go away. KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES, DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: Donald Trump is an unserious man, but the consequences of putting Donald Trump back in the White House are extremely serious. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You were in Chicago this week. What was your takeaway about that strategy and just about the way the convention?

utterances.speaker: MARIANNA SOTOMAYOR, CONGRESSIONAL REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, look how Democrats have changed. Obviously 2016, you had Michelle Obama saying, we're going to go high when the Republicans go low. 2020 Biden would really never mention Trump by name. He really tried to make a focus on the issues.Now, this campaign is all Trump, Trump, Trump. Look at Trump, he's weird, right? So we've seen this evolution among Democrats just trying to take Trump, the MAGA movement head-on. And I have to say, you know, there was that enthusiasm, but the Harris campaign is very aware that this hope, this feeling of hope and change that many Democrats were saying they felt from the Obama era has come back through Harris. They know that that doesn't necessarily move that -- those disaffected voters and those are the people that they're trying to turn out. And it's something -- it's part of their strategy to go to Southern Georgia, because it's interesting hearing them say, you know, we know we're going to lose some of these areas, but we want to lose less. And that is exactly what I hear from those very moderate swing district House Democrats in the midterms. We have to go to those areas where we know we're going to lose because it is very Republican, but if we can peel off some voters, that's going to make the difference to make sure that we can get reelected.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WOOTSON
utterances.sentences: -- it's not like us and all that stuff. And so the thought is that they sort of take them down a peg by saying, you've seen this playbook before you understand what Trump is. And as Kamala Harris was saying, that he's un-seriously -- unserious, and so they shouldn't take him serious. RAJUSo what is actually does that mean for this election? Just to look at the Pew Research poll that tested how county voters, how they have shifted over from July to August, 39 percent of Kennedy voters from July to August became Harris supporters. And it says actually should be 20 percent of Donald Trump's -- were Donald Trump supporters. So it just shows that the more -- that Trump has more to gain with this Kennedy endorsement than with now that he's gone behind him. But is that enough to change the dynamic of this race?

utterances.speaker: BALL
utterances.sentences: Well, we do see that in polls, in a lot of these swing states, that Trump has consistently done better in that two-person head-to- head. So at least in the hypothetical, it does help him when there's not that third option on the ballot.It does also help Harris a little bit, as you say, because some of those were the proverbial double haters that were just looking for a place to park their vote because they didn't like the two candidates in the major parties. And that's why his vote chair went down so much when Joe Biden dropped out was because a lot of those third-party voters were people who didn't like Biden or Trump. But the feeling of a lot of Democrats that I spoke to at the convention, while this was all happening while we were hearing that RFK was in the process of getting ready to drop out, was that they didn't -- they weren't too worried about it, in part, because they see him as part of this weird narrative. They see him as sort of a coup, right? He's an anti-vaxxer with a brain worm who has supported all kinds of conspiracy theories. And so they a lot of Democrats say, you know, we don't want him in our coalition. We want to be able to say those types of voters who believe those types of weird things they belong with Trump.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And very quickly, this is the Harris campaign. They haven't really engaged on this issue a whole lot. Is that a -- is that is risk by not engaging about?

utterances.speaker: JEFF MASON, WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT, REUTERS
utterances.sentences: They say they're not worried. And they -- and they say that's basically because she has already changed the equation that the voters that, as Molly was rightly saying, where risk of going to him are now coming over to her.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes. All right. We shall see.Up next, the top democratic pollster joins us. We'll ask her if Harris will get that fabled convention bump. And a comedian was roaming the halls of last week's convention. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: So just how big of a bump will Kamala Harris get out of the convention? And will it last?There's no question that over the past month, Harris has rebuilt the coalition that was framed under Joe Biden. But what about independence? And those in swing states who think our politics are too liberal. And will the enthusiasm we saw in Chicago last week be enough in November? Well, we have someone who can help answer some of these questions. And that's Celinda Lake, who is one of the Democratic Party's top pollsters, and, of course, is knee deep and all the numbers. Celinda, thanks for joining me.

utterances.speaker: CELINDA LAKE, POLLSTER AND POLITICAL CONSULTANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: I really appreciate it.So you're obviously a veteran of all these -- of these past conventions, if it bounces and past conventions. Just to remind viewers about what it typically looks like. There was not a bump back in 2020. That was the COVID year. There was obviously a different type of convention back then. But Clinton -- Hillary Clinton in 2016, about a seven point bump out of her convention. We see how Trump did, plus six. And then Obama, Romney, a small bump. Obama had a little bit of a bigger bump back in 2008. How do you see this moment? Is Harris' support already baked in? Or does she have significant room to grow?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: I think she has room to grow. But it's a very polarized race. It's going to be very close.In some ways, she already got the bounce before she even went into the convention.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And that's what lots of Democrats really worried about, right? I mean --

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: -- maybe that's -- maybe that's the peak.

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know if it's the peak, but it's a consolidation. And I think Democrats came out very, very energized.So we're going to see base turnout totally different in the amount -- it's illustrated by the number of volunteers, shifts, and then the amount of money raised, 40 percent of it from new donors. So that's already about. But it's going to be a fight for independence. It's going to be a fight for white and non-college educated women. It's going to be a fight for Latino men. And she's doing well with them right now.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: But where are her soft spots right now? We talked about some of them. Just look at the numbers here. Black voters under 30, Hispanic women. Those are all Harris has an advantage over Trump. Some to bigger margins than some others.Over 65 though, Harris is struggling. 43 to 57. That is according to CBS/YouGov poll. What explains that?

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm. But you also noted that there are some concern about women voters in particular, some non-college educated women voters in the suburbs.Is that where another key concern of Harris is at this moment?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Well, I think the key to winning for any Democrat is to win women by more than you lose men. So we've got to pick up these women who are sitting and undecided, like what they see, want change, but are worried there's good change and there's bad change.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes. And one of the questions, too, is about whether or not this is -- whether or not, Harris can make the case of being a change candidate versus, what Trump is trying to do, trying to painter as the de facto incumbent, being the vice president over the last four years.This is what Trump said in Glendale, Arizona. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The big message from their convention was that we need to turn the page from the failures of the last four years. Do you believe it? They forgot. They've run it for the last four years. She was saying last night, we will stop the abuse. We will stop the high taxes. I said that, you could have done it three and a half years ago.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: So this is just what the CBS /YouGov poll said about whether voters see Biden and Harris as the same, similar but not exactly alike according to this poll, mostly the same as Joe Biden, but not entirely, 64 percent of voters.Is that a concern for the Harris Party?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: No. I think, actually, I'm amazed at the number of voters who say, I want to take a look. I don't assume they were the same.And she has the benefit of people thinking she was in the room so she knows what she's doing. But she has a very different background. She's a new person. She has a new direction. And I want to see what she's proposing. So voters are remarkably open to saying, what is she proposing? What's she offering? And I'm surprised it is true as much as it is. But when you look at just, I mean, if you are, you know, you're looking at the numbers, you're diving into everything right now, what does Harris need to do with which part of the electorate in order to win in November? What is your biggest concern right now?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: I would say she needs to do three things. And she's doing all of them. One, she needs to introduce herself. It's a race -- she's not that well known with swing voters.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Even after the convention?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Even after the convention. Although the convention had record high viewership and she did a lot, she's got to build on that. And Trump is obviously trying to define her. Trump is already defined. Everybody knows what he's like. So it's a race to define her.Secondly, she's got to establish an economic profile. And she just launched an economic ad. And she has the money to, you know, spell out her program. She said, I'm in touch with what you're feeling. She said she's going to take on price gouging. She says the middle class need a tax break. Not another tax break for the wealthy people. And then she needs to maximize turnout. And she's already well on her way to doing that. Democrats and core constituencies is wildly enthusiastic about her.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes. We'll see if she can deal with those first two questions in the next 72 days.Celinda Lake, thank you so much for joining me and sharing your insight. Really appreciate it. LAKE: Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.And coming up, I caught up with Senate Majority Leader, Chuck Schumer, on what impact Harris will have down ticket, including in critical red states they need to win to keep the razor thin majority. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Facing one of the worst maps in years, Democrats in the Senate will likely need to run the table in November in order to simply keep the Senate at 50-50. And that includes in red states like Ohio and Montana.So, what does having Kamala Harris at the top of the ticket mean for their chances? Now, while several Democrats in swing Senate states races took the stage at the DNC last week, others stayed away, including Ohio's Sherrod Brown, Montana's Jon Tester, and purple state Democrat, Jacky Rosen of Nevada. And on the final day of the DNC, Tester even told reporters in Montana that he did not point to endorse a candidate for president at all. Now, in Chicago, I caught up with two top Senate Democrats, Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, and the head of the Senate Democratic campaign arm, Gary Peters, to talk about what Harris means for their most difficult races. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: What does Kamala Harris do for red states like in Ohio and Montana?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: Look, the bottom line is we'll have a great democratic program. She knows what average people think about.Look at the brilliance of putting forward this $25,000 break for first-time home buyers. 25 to 40 year olds who are doing pretty well. But one of their biggest problems is they still rent. And while they can afford the monthly mortgage payment, they can't afford the down payment. This is manna from heaven. Sherrod Brown will campaign on that. Jon Tester.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Tester doesn't even endorse her yet.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: He doesn't. He's going to talk about issues that they both care about.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You don't think it's a -- you don't think it's a -- you don't think it's a mistake that he hasn't endorsed her?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: I leave it to Jon Tester. He's going to win. He knows Montana better than anybody else.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Jon Tester has not endorsed Kamala Harris. Is that a mistake?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: He knows how to run his race. He knows what's best for Montana. You know, I'm going to let him make decisions on all the stuff that he does, whether it's endorsements or on issues. He's there representing the people of Montana.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: So I mean, you have at least three of your democratic incumbents, vulnerable members, who are not here. I mean, Tester, Brown, Jacky Rosen. Is that a good idea to keep their distance from the top of the ticket?

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: But do you think like someone like Jacky Rosen should be campaigning with Kamala Harris in Nevada?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: We'll see with you all. I expect she will.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: But I suppose you wouldn't want Kamala Harris stepping with Jon Tester and with Sherrod Brown.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: That's going to be up to them to decide whether or not how they want to the campaign. But again, you know, in our some of the tougher states, Montana, Ohio, these with both Jon Tester and Sherrod Brown, they've already proven that they can win in a tough state. And they are authentic. People know them. They're good at retail politics. And they're running against flawed Republicans.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: I mean, that's the interesting calculation that these candidates who are running in difficult races always have to make, how much distance to keep from the top of the ticket, how much to align themselves with the top of the ticket. We saw several candidates stump for Harris at the DNC, people from Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Michigan, even, but not so much Ohio and even Nevada. It's interesting. What do you think of Harris? What she means for the Democrats chances to keep the Senate already there was such a difficult map. But does she help? Does she hurt?

utterances.speaker: SOTOMAYOR
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it's an absolutely difficult map. And they've known this for several years. I mean, when you talk to Democrats, they're very excited about the general enthusiasm, right? Because that lacking of enthusiasm within the base, they were already thinking that's not going to help turn out voters. There could be voters who sit at home. That is less of a worry now.But I think to your point, I mean, there's always going to be your most vulnerable senators, your most vulnerable House Democrats who just are going to keep their distance. And we hear all the time from leaders saying they have to run the race, the way that they're going to run the race, whether they endorse or not, that's up to them. But it is interesting to me to see Congresswoman Slotkin, Tammy Baldwin, Senator Tammy Baldwin, they did not stump with Biden. They were purposely far away whenever they went to their states. Not only have they stumped with Harris already, but they were on the convention stage. So that to me is a shift where some of those still vulnerable seats, those members and senators representing those vulnerable districts and states are now embracing Harris a little bit more.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And split-ticket voting, though, doesn't really happen anymore in the Trump era. Only one time out of 69 races has a candidate from an opposing party won a race that was -- the presidential candidate from that opposite party carried. That's a challenge for people like Tester and Brown in Ohio and in Montana.

utterances.speaker: BALL
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. I mean, we can be almost certain that Trump is going to win both of those states, which means that Jon Tester cannot win without the support of a lot of Trump voters crossing over to vote for him.The candidate I was most surprised to see on stage giving a speech at the DNC was Colin Allred. He's running in Texas, another red state that Trump is almost certainly going to win. Although, of course, Democrats always talk about how they'd like to put it in play. But that tells me a couple things. Number one, that he gets so many donations from being up there on the national stage and saying I'm running against Ted Cruz that it's worth whatever hit he takes from being associated with the top of the ticket. And number two, that it's a different political calculation in a state like Texas where he's hoping that there's enough of an effect on the base, there's enough of a mobilization effect from the energy behind this new ticket, that that could be enough to put him in contention, particularly against a candidate like a Ted Cruz. But, you know, Politics 101, if you're Sherrod Brown, if you're a Jon Tester, you have to run your own race because you're not going to be able to win without those crossover voters.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: I would just add that the Kamala Harris campaign could care less whether it gets an endorsement from Jon Tester. And I don't mean that as a dismissal. I mean, you know, I spoke to somebody yesterday about this. Like, they just want people to win.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: So if that --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Which is also different than Trump. Trump wants loyalty.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: The Democrats have a completely different view of it.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: They don't care.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: The most important thing from their perspective is go out there and win and give her, if she wins as well, give her majorities in Congress.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And one question is, what will give them majorities in Congress? The issue of abortion. We know that abortion referendums are on a number of ballots in some key states. That includes Montana. That includes Florida. It's a reach state for Democrats to pick up.Maryland is a state that Democrats are trying to defend. They're also trying to defend Arizona and Nevada, all with abortion access issues on the ballot in November. So let me ask the Democratic leaders about that and about just the larger challenges facing a daunting map to keep the majority? (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You have three seats in states that Donald Trump picked up. You have incumbents in purple states. You have very difficult pickup opportunities. So how are you going to hang on to control the Senate?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Well, we are going to hang on. And it's -- you're correct, it's a very difficult map. But as you recall, I did this job last cycle, which was very tough in a midterm. Everybody thought we had no chance to hold the majority.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: This is worse. This is worse than last cycle.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: The fact that in Montana there's abortion on the ballot.

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Is that going to be decisive?

utterances.speaker: PETERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Do you think that will determine Jon Tester's ultimate outcome here? PETERS

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You talk about having to codify Roe v. Wade and a Democratic majority. But you know, you're not going to get, even if you manage to keep the Senate, you're not going to get 60 votes in the Senate. Does that mean that you may have to change the filibuster to do that?SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY) SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: Look, the bottom line is we looked at the filibuster once on voting rights and we're committed to doing that on other areas of the filibuster.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Including abortion rights?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.sentences: In other areas of the filibuster. We're going to talk as a caucus and see where to go. But let me say how potent an issue is in abortion. Jacky Rosen in the Cook poll, it's overwhelming. It's a little too optimistic, but it's up 18 points. What was the number one reason in my judgment? She's been advertising about abortion since June. And the Republicans are getting clobbered. They have no answer. And to be against IVF, give me a break. I have a grandchild who was born through IVF.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Republicans will say they're not against IVF, but nevertheless, the point being abortion, could that be enough to save the Democratic majority?

utterances.speaker: WOOTSON
utterances.sentences: Yes and no. I mean, Democrats have seen some success with abortion referendums, you know, in non-election cycles and all of that stuff. But I think that one of the things that Democrats are doing relatively successfully is making it about abortion, yes, but also painting the Republican Party writ large as sort of anti-freedom, taking away your rights, you know.So every Republican -- every race now becomes about whether you're going to give more power to Republicans who are just going to strip away more and more rights. And abortion is the linchpin of that argument, but it gets much larger.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: All right. We shall see. It's going to be a very difficult road for the Democrats, no question. Now coming up, while Harris was in Chicago, Trump was at the border. How Harris is trying to take on one of her biggest weaknesses.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Perhaps the biggest weakness for Kamala Harris and her party is the issue of immigration. And Democrats at the DNC this week tried to take it head on. The polls show it's not a top issue for many Democrats. It is a leading factor for the general electorate. And those persuadable middle-of-the-road voters were exactly who Harris and other Democrats were trying to reach this week. Their hope? Convince voters that Trump is the cause of the border crisis, and place the blame squarely on him for killing a bipartisan border security bill earlier this year.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) KAMALA HARRIS, (D) PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: After decades in law enforcement, I know the importance of safety and security, especially at our border. REP. TOM SUOZZI (D-NY): Let's be clear. The border is broken. But this year, when Democrats and Republicans worked together to finally write new border laws, we were blocked. SEN. CHRIS MURPHY (D-CT): Trump killed that bill. And he did it because he knew that if we fixed the border, he'd lose his ability to divide us. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: So will this work with voters? Just a look at the ABC, Washington Post, Ipsos poll, Trump versus Harris, registered voters, winning on several issues, including on immigration, which has really been the case for Trump's advantage for some time, 10 points, 46 to 36 over Harris on this issue.But what do you -- what does the Harris campaign think about this strategy? Is it effective -- they think it's actually -- absolutely think it's effective, but in your reporting, what are you learning on this?

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: Well, I think number one, they -- they absolutely want to emphasize blame and putting blame on Trump and showing that the Biden- Harris administration had a plan and that he torpedoed it. That gives them something to lift up but also to hide behind. Because as we were talking during the break, not all the Democrats in that room were super happy about that.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Many on the left were very, very angry about that bill.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: But it gives them a chance to say, look, this is President Trump's big issue. We tried to do something and he is the reason that it didn't happen. I don't -- you know, I asked somebody yesterday if there were plans for the Vice President to go to the border. No plans right now. But she does talk about immigration on the trail. It's not something she's shying away from. And I think that is a bit for those independent voters.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: So should she go to the border? There's a perfect segue.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.sentences: There's a segue for you. I teed it up for you.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You did. And I asked some Democrats at the convention last week if it would make sense politically for her to do that.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Should she do what Trump is doing, go and visit the border?REP. DAN KILDEE (D-MI): I mean, I think that would be helpful. Obviously, we think we have credibility on this issue where the President Trump does not.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Politically, would it make sense for her to just visit the border?REP. GERRY CONNOLLY (D-VA): If I were counseling her, I'd say, yeah, let's make a trip down there and get that over with. But I don't think she should do it in response to Trump. I think that shows weakness. So when the occasion happens, you pop down there with, you know, local officials who know the situation instead of grandstanding like Donald Trump is. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Still struggling about how to deal with this issue.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And the spending has been staggering on this issue, really, just look at the numbers between Republicans versus Democrats in spending on immigration at $72, $73 million for Republicans on immigration ads. That's just over the past month, $11 million for Democrats. So what exactly do those ads say? Here's a taste of what people are seeing in their living rooms.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: My son, Joshua, was 18 years old when he was murdered by an illegal alien. When I hear Kamala Harris making a joke about the border and just laughing it off, it's painful.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: She was tough enough to take on transnational gangs as a prosecutor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He almost killed me right over here. He was laughing as he fractured my skull.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Kamala put violent illegals, convicted felons back on the streets.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The lies from Donald Trump, the truth on Kamala Harris' watch, violent crime went down and Trump ordered MAGA extremists to kill the bipartisan border security bill.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And just before you jump in, Marianna, out of the $73 million that Republicans have spent on immigration ads, actually the total -- the total amount of ads they've spent in the last month is $90 million. So $73 million out of $90 million have been on immigration. That is what they believe their calling card is in order to win in November.

utterances.speaker: SOTOMAYOR
utterances.sentences: They know that this is the issue. And I think it's pretty significant here that Democrats did leave a void for too long of a time where Republicans have been able to successfully frame Democrats, successfully blame Harris as the borders are, even though she was assigned to deal with migration before getting to the -- before migrants got to the border.But still, this is something that we should absolutely expect them to keep talking about. Even when we return on Capitol Hill, I'm already hearing that the House Republican majority is going to be putting resolutions on the floor condemning Harris for a number of positions that she's taken on the border, on immigration. So this is, this not only motivates their base, but absolutely is front of mind as we pointed out to those independent voters.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, border crossings have dropped, but it was in the aftermath of Biden putting over those asylum restrictions that happened in June. I guess. So the question is, did the administration wait too long to really engage on this issue? WOOTSONI think a couple of things. One, I don't -- I don't think that she can avoid the issue of the border entirely, but I think that when she goes, or if she goes, she's definitely playing to their, you know, on -- on Trump's terms. It's just -- it's his issue. He's better at it. I also think that the left has been very silent, almost giving her a pass to move a little bit rightward and to talk more strongly about immigration.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yeah. All right. That's a great point. A great place to leave it at.And next stay tuned for some incredible political impersonations from Harris and Trump to Obama and Mitch McConnell. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Political conventions attract an eclectic mix of people, from politicians to delegates to people like Matt Friend. Friend is a comedian who's gained popularity for his spot-on impersonations of celebrities and politicians. I caught up with him this past week in Chicago, where he shared his impersonations of Donald Trump, Kamala Harris, and a host of others.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Matt Friend --

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Who am I talking to right now?

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: You see failing Kamala Harris, who's giving an address. She's just telling blatant lies.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: What about Kamala Harris?

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: Well, I can't quite do Kamala, but I can do Tim. When I win this election, I'm going to take a big thing of Gatorade and pour it right over Kamala's face. I'm feeling good about our chances.Kamala is tough, though. It's like that little -- I got to work on it.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Can you do the laugh?

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: I can't. I'm going to figure it out. I'm going to figure it out.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Have you met J.D. Vance yet?

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, it's such a weird thing. I was talking to my meema, my peepa, my weewa, my zeewa, and they all said, J.D., you're a great candidate.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Friend has also had his fun take on some CNNers.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Can you do me?

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: You have a little bit of a thing going on here. A little bit like a Ray Romano thing going on. I'm trying to figure it out, but keep talking. Keep talking.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: I think that is a little, little gravelier than my voice.

utterances.speaker: FRIEND
utterances.sentences: But I can do CNN's Chris Wallace. Welcome back to Who's Talking. I have Jake Tamper. What's up, TikTok besties? It's Jake Tapper.Yeah, I got to -- I was working on Axelrod, David Axelrod, Barack Obama's a great guy. (END VIDEO CLIP)
